Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Search for Anomalous Spin Interactions with Atomic Comagnetometers
Award.AbstractNarration:
Our research program encompasses two different projects. The first project is an experimental search for a long-range interaction between atomic spins and the mass of the Earth. Such an interaction could arise due to a heretofore undiscovered "fifth force" or if gravity, as opposed to being a purely tensor interaction as assumed in general relativity, has a scalar/pseudoscalar component. Recent theoretical work has shown that such interactions could be the cause of the accelerating expansion of the universe, commonly attributed to dark energy. Our experiment seeks to detect this effect by simultaneously measuring the spin precession of two isotopes of rubidium using laser spectroscopy. Our experiment aims to improve experimental sensitivity to long-range spin-mass interactions by 1-3 orders of magnitude. Our second project focuses on development of a prototype sensor for the Global Network of Optical Magnetometers for Exotic physics (GNOME), an array of geographically separated, time-synchronized ultrasensitive atomic comagnetometers that will search for correlated transient signals heralding new physics. The GNOME would be sensitive to nuclear and electron spin couplings to various exotic particles and fields. To date, no such search has ever been carried out, making the GNOME a novel experimental window on new physics. A specific, feasible example of new physics detectable with the GNOME, presently unconstrained by astrophysical observations and laboratory experiments, is a network of domain walls of light pseudoscalar fields.

Our present understanding of fundamental physics is confronted by a number of deep mysteries: the origin of the matter-antimatter asymmetry of the universe, the nature of dark energy, and the nature of dark matter. Our experiments, conducted in laboratories on Earth, use precise measurements of atomic spins to test several hypotheses that might explain these mysteries. It has been proposed that if our present theory of gravity is incomplete, additional components of gravity could both generate the dark energy pushing the universe apart and produce an excess of matter over antimatter after the Big Bang. These additional components of gravity would also cause atomic spins to precess in the Earth's gravitational field, the effect for which our experiment will search. A possible explanation of dark matter is a network of invisible galactic-scale "domain walls" that store considerable mass and energy. These invisible domain walls would exert a small torque on atomic spins that could be detected when the Earth passes through a wall. We are building a prototype sensor sensitive to such torques from domain wall-crossing events. An array of time-synchronized sensors based on our prototype will search for transient signals of astrophysical origin heralding such new physics. Our research is being carried out at a public undergraduate institution with a diverse student body, providing hands-on experience in state-of-the-art experimental physics to many undergraduate students (including a significant number of women and underrepresented minorities).

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this multi-faceted research project, we searched for heretofore undiscovered exotic interactions with far greater precision than previous experiments:

(1) We carried out a search for a long-range coupling between rubidium nuclear spins and the mass of the Earth, which can be interpreted as a spin-gravity interaction. The experimental constraints we established for protons surpass those of previous laboratory searches by more than a factor of 1000. 

(2) We used spectroscopy of helium and measurements of strontium ions to search for exotic spin-spin interactions between electrons, establishing the first such experimental limits below the micron scale.

Another major part of our research project was the construction, testing, and characterization a network of geographically separated, time-synchronized ultrasensitive atomic magnetometers to search for correlated transient signals heralding new physics known as the Global Network of Optical Magnetometers to search for Exotic physics (GNOME). The GNOME is now fully operational and we carried out our first science run to search for terrestrial encounters with compact dark matter objects. Prior to our first science run, no such search had ever been carried out, making the GNOME a completely novel experimental window on new physics.

One of the most exciting discoveries during the course of our research is the invention of an entirely new tool with which to search for exotic spin-dependent interactions of electrons that, in principle, could offer sensitivity 100,000 times beyond that of present technology. We have predicted that a ferromagnetic needle will precess about the magnetic field axis if the needle is sufficiently small and the field is sufficiently small. In this regime the needle behaves as a gyroscope, and represents a correlated system of spins for which magnetic fields can be measured for long times, under which conditions the magnetometric sensitivity can in principle far surpass that of existing magnetometers based on spin precession of atoms in the gas phase.

Ultimately, the most important result of our project is the broader impact of the work on our students and community. Since California State University - East Bay's Physics Department is undergraduate-only, all the students who have been involved in this project are undergraduates, and ultimately much of the time and effort dedicated to this research program was devoted to training the students. Our students have learned about all areas of experimental research: design, contruction, and troubleshooting of optical and electronic components, computer programming for data acquisition and analysis, techniques for investigation of systematic errors, and communication skills for presentation of their results at regional and national conferences. Numerous students have been co-authors of peer-reviewed publications.

Prior to the beginning of this long-term research program, there had never been an externally funded research project in the California State University East Bay Physics Department. Since the beginning of our research program in 2007, more than forty undergraduate students have worked in our research laboratory. Our students have won awards for their research, gone on to excellent jobs in the high-tech industry, and enrolled in top Ph.D. programs. Three recent graduates working in our laboratory have been awarded prestigious NSF Graduate Research Fellowships. The undergraduate students at California State University - East Bay are extremely diverse: California State University - East Bay has been repeatedly named by the Chronicle of Higher Education as the most diverse university in the continental United States, and a majority of our undergraduate research students over the past decade have been underrepresented minorities. California State University - East Bay is federally recognized as both a Hispanic Serving Institution and a Asian and Pacific Islander Serving Institution.
